Definitions.Definition_Content: A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is finite if $B$ is a finite $A$-module under $\varphi$. This is also referred to as $B$ being finite over $A$ or, if $\varphi$ is an inclusion homomorphism, that the extension $A \hookrightarrow B$ is finite.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is of finite type if there exists an epimorphism $\Phi: A[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}] \longrightarrow B$ from a polynomial ring in finitely many variables over $A$ to $B$ that extends $\varphi$. Alternatively, it can be characterized by the existence of elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in B$ such that $B=\varphi(A)[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}]$.

An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: For a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ and an element $b \in B$, the following conditions are equivalent: (i) There exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]. (ii) The subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated. (iii) Viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M.
Every finite ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$ is integral.

Let $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ be a ring homomorphism of finite type and assume $B=A[b_{1}, \ldots, b_{r}]$ for elements $b_{1}, \ldots, b_{r} \in B$ that are integral over $A$. Then $A \longrightarrow B$ is finite and, in particular, integral.
Let $A \longrightarrow B$ and $B \longrightarrow C$ be two finite (resp. integral) ring homomorphisms. Then their composition $A \longrightarrow C$ is also finite (resp. integral).

Let $K$ be a field and $K \hookrightarrow B$ a nonzero $K$-algebra of finite type. Then there exist elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r} \in B$ such that $B$ is finite over the subring $K[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}] \subset B$, while the system $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r} \in B$ is algebraically independent over $K$.
Let $A \hookrightarrow B$ be an integral extension of integral domains. If one of the rings $A$ and $B$ is a field, then the same is true for the other as well.

Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension satisfying $L=K[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}]$ for some elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in L$, i.e., assume that $K \subset L$, as a ring extension, is of finite type. Then the extension $K \subset L$ is finite.

Let $K[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}]$ be the polynomial ring in $n$ variables over a field $K$ and let $\mathfrak{m} \subset K[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}]$ be a maximal ideal. Then the canonical map $K \longrightarrow K[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}] / \mathfrak{m}=L$ is finite, so that $L / K$ is a finite field extension.
Given a ring extension $R \subset R'$, the inclusion map $R \hookrightarrow R'$ can always be viewed as a ring homomorphism.
